title: Who are the descendants of the Vikings? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s important to understand that “Viking” was not a culture, ethnicity or a nation. It was an occupation. The people who originally resided in Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland were collectively known as “Norse” or “Northmen”. The ones who sailed on longboats to distant shores for conquest, raiding and exploration were said to go “a-viking”. Only about 10% of the Norse went a-viking. The rest were farmers, craftsmen, blacksmiths, shipbuilders, lawyers, merchants, traders, etc. When they started converting to Christianity, the a-viking raids started to phase out. As for their descendants, mostly they can be fond in the countries listed above: Denmark, Norway, Sweden, and Finland. The Norse settled in Iceland and stayed there. They also had settlements in Britain, so one can say that there is a decent amount of Norse DNA floating around the British Isles. Around 911 C.E., they settled on the coast of Western France, creating the Duchy of Normandy. They would become the Normans which invaded and conquered England in 1066. Many Norse descendants ended up in America (I’m one of them… my Gr-Gr-Gr-Grandparents came from Norway). Then there was a group of Norse known as the “Rus”, living on the Eastern shore of Sweden. They explored Eastward into the unknown land that the Romans called “Sarmatia”. They traveled deep into this territory and around the year 1100 C.E. they founded a settlement right near the location where the Neglinnaya River empties into the Moskva River. This settlement would grow up into what is known today as Moscow. The Rus became the Russians, and the land was named “Russia”. Also, as Dee stated, the Norse had extensive trade routes throughout Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. So it’s possible that you will find various degrees of Norse DNA in those places as well.
